title: Fazlallah Khunji Isfahani
text: Fazlallah Khunji Isfahani (), was a <a href="Persians">Persian</a> religious scholar, historian and political writer. He was born in 1455 in <a href="Shiraz">Shiraz</a>, a city in <a href="Fars%20Province">Fars</a>, a region in southern Iran. His father belonged to the Ruzbihan family, which was descended from the <a href="Sufism">Sufi</a> author <a href="Ruzbihan%20Baqli">Ruzbihan Baqli</a> (died 1209), while his mother belonged to the Sa'idi family. Through both his parents, Khunji belonged to the affluent and infuential "<a href="ulama">ulama</a>" (clergical class) of Fars, who were respected and protected by the <a href="Turkoman%20%28ethnonym%29">Turkmen</a> <a href="Aq%20Qoyunlu">Aq Qoyunlu</a>. In 1487, Khunji left Shiraz for the third time for a <a href="Hajj">Hajj</a>. He met <a href="Sultan">Sultan</a> <a href="Yaqub%20bin%20Uzun%20Hasan">Ya'qub</a> of Aq Qoyunlu near the <a href="Sahand%20mountain">Sahand mountain</a> and agreed to write the history of Aq Qoyunlu dynasty. When the <a href="Safavid%20dynasty">Safavid</a> <a href="shah">shah</a> <a href="Ismail%20I">Ismail I</a> started the <a href="Safavid%20conversion%20of%20Iran%20to%20Shia%20Islam">Shi'ification of Iran</a> and the persecution of Sunni Muslims, Khunji fled to <a href="Transoxiana">Transoxiana</a>, where he lived for the rest of his life under the patronage of <a href="Timurids">Timurids</a> and <a href="Shaybanids">Shaybanids</a>.
